messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the complexity of isomorphism problems for tensors, groups, and polynomials IV: linear-length reductions and their applications

Paper Abstract: Abstract Many isomorphism problems for tensors, groups, algebras, and polynomials were recently shown to be equivalent to one another under polynomial-time reductions, prompting the introduction of the complexity class 𝖳𝖨𝖳𝖨\mathsf{TI} (Grochow & Qiao, ITCS ’21; SIAM J. Comp., ’23). Using the tensorial viewpoint, Grochow & Qiao (CCC ’21) then gave moderately exponential-time search- and counting-to-decision reductions for a class of p𝑝p-groups. A significant issue was that the reductions usually incurred a quadratic increase in the length of the tensors involved. When the tensors represent p𝑝p-groups, this corresponds to an increase in the order of the group of the form |G|Θ​(log⁡|G|)superscript𝐺Θ𝐺|G|^{\Theta(\log|G|)}, negating any asymptotic gains in the Cayley table model. In this paper, we present a new kind of tensor gadget that allows us to replace those quadratic-length reductions with linear-length ones, yielding the following consequences: 1. Combined with the recent breakthrough |G|O​((log⁡|G|)5/6)superscript𝐺𝑂superscript𝐺56|G|^{O((\log|G|)^{5/6})}-time isomorphism-test for p𝑝p-groups of class 2 and exponent p𝑝p (Sun, STOC ’23), our reductions extend this runtime to p𝑝p-groups of class c𝑐c and exponent p𝑝p where c<p𝑐𝑝c<p. 2. Our reductions show that Sun’s algorithm solves several 𝖳𝖨𝖳𝖨\mathsf{TI}-complete problems over a finite prime field 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, such as isomorphism problems for cubic forms, algebras, and tensors, in time pO​(n1.8​log⁡p)superscript𝑝𝑂superscript𝑛1.8𝑝p^{O(n^{1.8}\log p)}, where n𝑛n is the side length. When n≫(log⁡p)5much-greater-than𝑛superscript𝑝5n\gg(\log p)^{5}, this improves over the previous state of the art, which was the brute-force upper bound of pO​(n2)superscript𝑝𝑂superscript𝑛2p^{O(n^{2})}. 3. Polynomial-time search- and counting-to-decision reduction for testing isomorphism of p𝑝p-groups of class 222 and exponent p𝑝p in the Cayley table model. This answers questions of Arvind and Tóran (Bull. EATCS, 2005) for this group class, thought to be one of the hardest cases of Group Isomorphism. 4. If Graph Isomorphism is in 𝖯𝖯\mathsf{P}, then testing equivalence of cubic forms in n𝑛n variables over a finite field 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, and testing isomorphism of n𝑛n-dimensional algebras over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, can both be solved in time qO​(n)superscript𝑞𝑂𝑛q^{O(n)}, improving from the brute-force upper bound qO​(n2)superscript𝑞𝑂superscript𝑛2q^{O(n^{2})} for both of these. Our reductions are also presented in a more modular and composable fashion compared to previous gadgets, making them easier to reason about and, crucially, easier to combine.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Zero knowledge and circuit minimization",
        "Equivalence of 𝔽𝔽\\mathbb{F}-algebras and cubic forms",
        "Isomorphism testing: Perspective and open problems",
        "Graph isomorphism in quasipolynomial time [extended abstract]",
        "Groups with abelian central quotient group",
        "Code equivalence and group isomorphism",
        "Geometric complexity theory and tensor rank",
        "Improved algorithms for alternating matrix space isometry: From theory to practice",
        "Linear algebraic groups, volume 126",
        "Exact and asymptotic measures of multipartite pure-state entanglement",
        "On the hardness of code equivalence problems in rank metric",
        "On the complexity of isomorphism problems for tensors, groups, and polynomials III: some results over classical groups",
        "Automorphism group computation and isomorphism testing in finite groups",
        "Monomial isomorphism for tensors and applications to code equivalence problems",
        "Wildness for tensors",
        "On a programme for the determination of the automorphism group of a finite group",
        "Algorithms for group isomorphism via group extensions and cohomology",
        "Isomorphism problems for tensors, groups, and cubic forms: completeness and reductions",
        "On p𝑝p-group isomorphism: search-to-decision, counting-to-decision, and nilpotency class reductions via tensors",
        "On the complexity of isomorphism problems for tensors, groups, and polynomials I: Tensor Isomorphism-completeness",
        "Average-case algorithms for testing isomorphism of polynomials, algebras, and multilinear forms",
        "Matrix Lie algebra isomorphism",
        "Answer to “what is the hardest instance for the group isomorphism problem?” on cstheory.stackexchange.com",
        "Algorithms based on *-algebras, and their applications to isomorphism of polynomials with one secret, group isomorphism, and polynomial identity testing",
        "General linear group action on tensors: A candidate for post-quantum cryptography",
        "Representations of Permutation Groups I: Representations of Wreath Products and Applications to the Representation Theory of Symmetric and Alternating Groups, volume 240",
        "p𝑝p-automorphisms of finite p𝑝p-groups, volume 246 of London Mathematical Society Lecture Note Series",
        "Complexity of ring morphism problems",
        "The graph isomorphism problem: its structural complexity",
        "Sur les groupes nilpotents et les anneaux de Lie",
        "Linear algebraic analogues of the graph isomorphism problem and the Erdős–Rényi model",
        "Connections between graphs and matrix spaces",
        "Isomorphism of graphs of bounded valence can be tested in polynomial time",
        "Hypergraph isomorphism and structural equivalence of boolean functions",
        "Isomorphism in expanding families of indistinguishable groups",
        "A note on the graph isomorphism counting problem",
        "On the nlog⁡nsuperscript𝑛𝑛n^{\\log n} isomorphism technique (a preliminary report)",
        "Automorphisms of random graphs with specified vertices",
        "Lazard correspondence up to isoclinism",
        "Hidden fields equations (HFE) and isomorphisms of polynomials (IP): two new families of asymmetric algorithms",
        "Is code equivalence easy to decide?",
        "Learning paths from signature tensors",
        "Hardness estimates of the Code Equivalence Problem in the rank metric",
        "Faster isomorphism for p𝑝p-groups of class 2 and exponent p𝑝p",
        "Practical post-quantum signature schemes from isomorphism problems of trilinear forms",
        "Models of random regular graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the complexity of isomorphism problems for tensors, groups, and polynomials IV: linear-length reductions and their applications, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
